Award.AwardTitle: NSWP: Causal Electron Precipitation in Geospace Weather: Model Development, Validation, Event Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is motivated by the overarching question: How does spatiotemporal variability in regional and global characteristics of electron precipitation influence the magnetosphere-ionosphere (MI) interaction? The precipitation of electrons from the magnetosphere into the ionosphere alters the electrical properties of the ionosphere. By altering the electrical conductance of the ionosphere as well as the scale height, electron precipitation plays a primary agent in regulating both the electrodynamics of magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling, but also the gravitational escape of ionospheric ions into space. For these reasons, characteristics of electron precipitation such as its flux distributions and its hemispheric power are recognized as key variables for space weather prediction. Current understanding of the effects of electron precipitation has been derived largely from index-based, non-causal empirical precipitation models and from simple first-principles models embedded in global simulations of the magnetosphere. Neither approach adequately captures the complexity or variability of electron precipitation that occurs during major space weather events such as magnetic storms. This project takes a major step in advancing the state-of-the-art by developing physically realistic electron precipitation models that can be causally regulated by state variables derived from global magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations of the magnetosphere. The principal science objectives are i) to improve the fidelity of the electron precipitation fluxes predicted in numerical simulations of the geospace environment, and ii) to use the simulations to investigate the effects of electron precipitation on the MI interaction. Anticipated innovations include improvements in the specification of direct-entry, diffuse and monoenergetic precipitation and development of new models for secondary and broadband precipitation. The proposed developments will be will be tested and their accuracy calibrated in the context of a standalone version of the Lyon-Fedder-Mobarry (LFM) global simulation model as well as the coupled magnetosphere- ionosphere-thermosphere (CMIT) model, which merges the LFM model and the thermosphere-ionosphere electrodynamics general circulation model (TIEGCM). The LFM model will be used to study precipitation, field-aligned currents, convection, and joule dissipation; the TIEGCM will be used to study the impacts of precipitation on the distribution and dynamics of E- and F-region ionization and the resulting electrical conductivities.
The project integrates research and education by advancing discovery and understanding while promoting the teaching and professional development of a PhD student who will perform the bulk of the research under the mentorship of the principal investigator and his collaborators. The project will enhance the infrastructure for research and education by fostering a partnership between participating scientists at Dartmouth College and the National Center for Atmospheric Research. Project results will be disseminated in public forums, in refereed journal publications and in conference presentations. Legacies include innovative precipitation models that can be implemented in any global MHD simulation model of the magnetosphere; benefit to society by advancing our capability to forecast geospace weather; and a deeper scientific understanding of causal relationships between the physical attributes and the impacts of electron precipitation in geospace.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Charged-particle precipitation from space into EarthÆs upper atmosphere (the thermosphere) is the geospace analog of rain in EarthÆs troposphere. This project was motivated by the overarching question: How does spatiotemporal vari­ability in regional and global characteristics of electron precipitation influence the magneto­sphere-iono­sphere-thermosphere (MIT) interaction in space? Electron precipitation modifies the electrical properties and the scale height of the iono­sphere, so it is a primary agent in regulating both the electrodynam­ics of the MIT interaction and the gravitational escape of ionospheric ions into geospace and beyond. For these rea­sons, characteristics of electron precipitation such as its flux distributions and its hemi­spheric power are recognized as key variables for space weather prediction. The project developed physical predictive models for electron and proton precipitation that are now embedded in a global geospace simulation model that can be used to forecast space weather – the analogue of a numerical forecast model for ordinary weather. Model results were validated against empirical models derived from more than 10 years of satellite data (the Ovation Prime model) and against actual geomagnetic storm events for which global distributions of electron precipitation could be derived from inversion algorithms for satellite images acquired in the far ultraviolet. The resulting precipitation models were also used to investigate and resolve several outstanding problems in geospace science, including the physical processes controlling: 1) spatial and temporal distributions and diurnal asymmetries of fluctuating electromagnetic power flows into the polar ionosphere as recorded by polar orbiting satellites; 2) average spatial distributions of thermospheric upwelling in the postnoon and premidnight high-latitude regions recorded by satellites experiencing anomalous atmospheric drag at 400-km altitude; 3) development of periodic (sawtooth) oscillations in large-scale flows and magnetic structure in EarthÆs magnetotail and nightside plasma sheet associated with deposition of fluctuating electromagnetic power in EarthÆs ionosphere and resulting outflows of singly ionized oxygen from the ionosphere; and 4) development of nightside auroral structure in auroral precipitation observed by the CASCADES 2 auroral sounding rocket. The project contributed directly to human resource development in STEM disciplines by sponsoring a PhD dissertation and partially sponsoring an MS thesis and a senior honors thesis. Participants in the project served as mentors for these students. The student completing the senior thesis will start a PhD program in engineering in Fall 2014 at Duke University; the student completing theMS is now working in the IT sector; and the student completing thePhD is working at Dartmouth as a research sientist. The project has helped build and foster close collaborations and exchanges between scientists and students at Dartmouth College and the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colorado. The physical predictive models developed by the project will improve our NationÆs ability to numerically forecast key aspects of space weather. The project generated considerable public interest through general audience presentations at annual open house events and in a public lecture at Dartmouth's Thayer School of Engineering.
